trans-unit.source: When developing applications for Azure, identity and access are the primary security concerns that you need to keep in mind.
trans-unit.target: When developing applications for Azure, identity and access are the primary security concerns that you need to keep in mind.

trans-unit.source: This topic explains the key security concerns related to identity and access in the cloud and how you can best protect your cloud applications.
trans-unit.target: This topic explains the key security concerns related to identity and access in the cloud and how you can best protect your cloud applications.

trans-unit.source: An application's security is a function of its surface.
trans-unit.target: An application's security is a function of its surface.

trans-unit.source: The more surface that the application exposes the greater the security concerns.
trans-unit.target: The more surface that the application exposes the greater the security concerns.

trans-unit.source: For example, an application that runs as an unattended batch process exposes less, from a security perspective, than a publicly available website.
trans-unit.target: For example, an application that runs as an unattended batch process exposes less, from a security perspective, than a publicly available website.

trans-unit.source: When you move to the cloud you gain a certain peace of mind about infrastructure and networking since these are managed in data centers with world-class security practices, tools, technology.
trans-unit.target: When you move to the cloud you gain a certain peace of mind about infrastructure and networking since these are managed in data centers with world-class security practices, tools, technology.

trans-unit.source: On the other hand, the cloud intrinsically exposes more surface area for your application that can be potentially exploited by attackers.
trans-unit.target: On the other hand, the cloud intrinsically exposes more surface area for your application that can be potentially exploited by attackers.

trans-unit.source: This is because many cloud technologies and services are exposed as end points vs. in-memory components.
trans-unit.target: This is because many cloud technologies and services are exposed as end points vs. in-memory components.

trans-unit.source: Azure storage, Service Bus, SQL Database (formerly SQL Azure), and many other services are accessible via their endpoints over the wire.
trans-unit.target: Azure storage, Service Bus, SQL Database (formerly SQL Azure), and many other services are accessible via their endpoints over the wire.

trans-unit.source: In cloud applications more responsibility lays on the shoulders of the application developers to design, develop, and maintain their cloud applications to high security standards to keep attackers at bay.
trans-unit.target: In cloud applications more responsibility lays on the shoulders of the application developers to design, develop, and maintain their cloud applications to high security standards to keep attackers at bay.

trans-unit.source: Consider the following diagram (from J.D. Meier's <linkText>Azure Security Notes PDF</linkText><title></title>): notice how the infrastructure part is being addressed by the cloud provider--in our case by Azure--leaving more security work to the application developers:
trans-unit.target: Consider the following diagram (from J.D. Meier's <linkText>Azure Security Notes PDF</linkText><title></title>): notice how the infrastructure part is being addressed by the cloud provider--in our case by Azure--leaving more security work to the application developers:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Securing the application</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Securing the application</linkText>

trans-unit.source: The good news is that all of the security development practices, principles, and techniques you already know still apply when developing cloud applications.
trans-unit.target: The good news is that all of the security development practices, principles, and techniques you already know still apply when developing cloud applications.

trans-unit.source: Consider the following key areas that must be addressed:
trans-unit.target: Consider the following key areas that must be addressed:

trans-unit.source: All input is validated for type, length, range, and string patterns to avoid injection attacks, and all the data your app echoes back is properly sanitized.
trans-unit.target: All input is validated for type, length, range, and string patterns to avoid injection attacks, and all the data your app echoes back is properly sanitized.

trans-unit.source: Sensitive data should be protected at rest and on the wire to mitigate information disclosure and data tampering threats.
trans-unit.target: Sensitive data should be protected at rest and on the wire to mitigate information disclosure and data tampering threats.

trans-unit.source: Auditing and logging must be properly implemented to mitigate non repudiation threats.
trans-unit.target: Auditing and logging must be properly implemented to mitigate non repudiation threats.

trans-unit.source: Authentication and Authorization should be implemented using proven mechanisms offered by the platform to prevent identity spoofing and elevation of privileges threats.
trans-unit.target: Authentication and Authorization should be implemented using proven mechanisms offered by the platform to prevent identity spoofing and elevation of privileges threats.

trans-unit.source: For a complete list of threats, attacks, vulnerabilities, and countermeasures refer to patterns & practices' <linkText>Cheat Sheet: Web Application Security Frame</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Security Guidance for Applications Index</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For a complete list of threats, attacks, vulnerabilities, and countermeasures refer to patterns & practices' <linkText>Cheat Sheet: Web Application Security Frame</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Security Guidance for Applications Index</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the cloud, authentication and access control mechanisms are very different than those available for on-premises applications.
trans-unit.target: In the cloud, authentication and access control mechanisms are very different than those available for on-premises applications.

trans-unit.source: There are many more authentication and access options offered for cloud applications that can lead to confusion, and as a result, to flawed implementations.
trans-unit.target: There are many more authentication and access options offered for cloud applications that can lead to confusion, and as a result, to flawed implementations.

trans-unit.source: More confusion is introduced when defining what a cloud app is.
trans-unit.target: More confusion is introduced when defining what a cloud app is.

trans-unit.source: For example, the application could be deployed to the cloud yet its authentication mechanism might be provided by Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: For example, the application could be deployed to the cloud yet its authentication mechanism might be provided by Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: On other hand, the application could be deployed on-premises but with authentication mechanisms in the cloud (for example, by Azure Active Directory Access Control (previously known as Access Control Service or ACS)).
trans-unit.target: On other hand, the application could be deployed on-premises but with authentication mechanisms in the cloud (for example, by Azure Active Directory Access Control (previously known as Access Control Service or ACS)).

trans-unit.source: A threat is a potential bad outcome that you want to avoid such as the disclosure of sensitive information or a service becoming unavailable.
trans-unit.target: A threat is a potential bad outcome that you want to avoid such as the disclosure of sensitive information or a service becoming unavailable.

trans-unit.source: It is common practice to classify threats by using the acronym "STRIDE":
trans-unit.target: It is common practice to classify threats by using the acronym "STRIDE":

trans-unit.source: Spoofing or identity theft
trans-unit.target: Spoofing or identity theft

trans-unit.source: Tampering with data
trans-unit.target: Tampering with data

trans-unit.source: Repudiation of actions
trans-unit.target: Repudiation of actions

trans-unit.source: Information disclosure
trans-unit.target: Information disclosure

trans-unit.source: Denial of service
trans-unit.target: Denial of service

trans-unit.source: Elevation of privileges
trans-unit.target: Elevation of privileges

trans-unit.source: Vulnerabilities are bugs that we, as developers, introduce into the code that make an application exploitable by attackers.
trans-unit.target: Vulnerabilities are bugs that we, as developers, introduce into the code that make an application exploitable by attackers.

trans-unit.source: For example, sending sensitive data in clear text makes an information disclosure threat possible by a traffic sniffing attack.
trans-unit.target: For example, sending sensitive data in clear text makes an information disclosure threat possible by a traffic sniffing attack.

trans-unit.source: Attacks are the exploitation of those vulnerabilities to cause harm to an application.
trans-unit.target: Attacks are the exploitation of those vulnerabilities to cause harm to an application.

trans-unit.source: For example, a Cross Site Scripting, or XSS, is an attack that exploits unsanitized output.
trans-unit.target: For example, a Cross Site Scripting, or XSS, is an attack that exploits unsanitized output.

trans-unit.source: Another example is eavesdropping on the wire to capture credentials sent in clear.
trans-unit.target: Another example is eavesdropping on the wire to capture credentials sent in clear.

trans-unit.source: These attacks can lead to an identity spoof threat being realized.
trans-unit.target: These attacks can lead to an identity spoof threat being realized.

trans-unit.source: To make it simple consider threats, vulnerabilities, and attacks as bad things.
trans-unit.target: To make it simple consider threats, vulnerabilities, and attacks as bad things.

trans-unit.source: Consider the following diagrams as a balcony view of the bad things related to a Web application deployed to Azure (from J.D. Meier's <linkText>Azure Security Notes PDF</linkText><title></title>):
trans-unit.target: Consider the following diagrams as a balcony view of the bad things related to a Web application deployed to Azure (from J.D. Meier's <linkText>Azure Security Notes PDF</linkText><title></title>):

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Threats Vulnerabilities and Attacks</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Threats Vulnerabilities and Attacks</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You, as a developer, have control over the vulnerabilities.
trans-unit.target: You, as a developer, have control over the vulnerabilities.

trans-unit.source: The fewer vulnerabilities that you introduce, the fewer options that are left to attacker to exploit.
trans-unit.target: The fewer vulnerabilities that you introduce, the fewer options that are left to attacker to exploit.

trans-unit.source: Identity and access related vulnerabilities leave you open to all threats in the STRIDE model.
trans-unit.target: Identity and access related vulnerabilities leave you open to all threats in the STRIDE model.

trans-unit.source: For example, an improperly implemented authentication mechanism may lead to an identity spoof and, as a result, information disclosure, data tampering, elevated privileges operations, or even shutting down the service altogether.
trans-unit.target: For example, an improperly implemented authentication mechanism may lead to an identity spoof and, as a result, information disclosure, data tampering, elevated privileges operations, or even shutting down the service altogether.

trans-unit.source: Consider the following questions that may point to potential vulnerabilities in your cloud app's identity and access implementation:
trans-unit.target: Consider the following questions that may point to potential vulnerabilities in your cloud app's identity and access implementation:

trans-unit.source: Are you sending credentials in clear over the wire to your Azure services?
trans-unit.target: Are you sending credentials in clear over the wire to your Azure services?

trans-unit.source: Do you store Azure services credentials in clear?
trans-unit.target: Do you store Azure services credentials in clear?

trans-unit.source: Do your Azure services credentials follow strong password policies?
trans-unit.target: Do your Azure services credentials follow strong password policies?

trans-unit.source: Do you rely on Azure to verify credentials vs. using custom verification mechanisms?
trans-unit.target: Do you rely on Azure to verify credentials vs. using custom verification mechanisms?

trans-unit.source: Do you limit Azure services authentication sessions or token lifetime to a reasonable time window?
trans-unit.target: Do you limit Azure services authentication sessions or token lifetime to a reasonable time window?

trans-unit.source: Do you verify permissions for each Azure entry point of your distributed cloud app?
trans-unit.target: Do you verify permissions for each Azure entry point of your distributed cloud app?

trans-unit.source: Does your authorization mechanism fail securely without exposing sensitive information, or without allowing limitless access?
trans-unit.target: Does your authorization mechanism fail securely without exposing sensitive information, or without allowing limitless access?

trans-unit.source: The best countermeasure against an attack is by using the identity and access mechanisms offered by the platform rather than implementing your own.
trans-unit.target: The best countermeasure against an attack is by using the identity and access mechanisms offered by the platform rather than implementing your own.

trans-unit.source: Consider the following prominent identity and access technologies:
trans-unit.target: Consider the following prominent identity and access technologies:

trans-unit.source: Windows Identity Foundation (WIF). WIF is a .NET runtime library included with the .NET Framework 4.5 (it is also available as separate download for .NET 3.5/4.0).
trans-unit.target: Windows Identity Foundation (WIF). WIF is a .NET runtime library included with the .NET Framework 4.5 (it is also available as separate download for .NET 3.5/4.0).

trans-unit.source: WIF does the heavy lifting for handling protocols such as WS-Federation and WS-Trust and tokens handling such as Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) so you don't need to write very complex security-related code in your application.
trans-unit.target: WIF does the heavy lifting for handling protocols such as WS-Federation and WS-Trust and tokens handling such as Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) so you don't need to write very complex security-related code in your application.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD Access Control (previously known as ACS).
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Access Control (previously known as ACS).

trans-unit.source: Azure AD Access Control is a cloud service that provides Security Token Service (STS) and allows federation with different identity providers (IdPs) such as a corporate Active Directory or Internet IdPs such as Windows Live ID / Microsoft Account, Facebook, Google, Yahoo!, and Open ID 2.0 identity providers.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Access Control is a cloud service that provides Security Token Service (STS) and allows federation with different identity providers (IdPs) such as a corporate Active Directory or Internet IdPs such as Windows Live ID / Microsoft Account, Facebook, Google, Yahoo!, and Open ID 2.0 identity providers.

trans-unit.source: This section briefly outlines the key scenarios covered in this topic.
trans-unit.target: This section briefly outlines the key scenarios covered in this topic.

trans-unit.source: Use it as a map to determine the right identity solution for your application.
trans-unit.target: Use it as a map to determine the right identity solution for your application.

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET Web Form Application with Federated Authentication. In this scenario you control access to your ASP.NET Web Forms app using either Internet identity such as Live ID / Microsoft Account or corporate identity managed in Windows Server Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET Web Form Application with Federated Authentication. In this scenario you control access to your ASP.NET Web Forms app using either Internet identity such as Live ID / Microsoft Account or corporate identity managed in Windows Server Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: WCF (SOAP) Service with Federated Authentication.In this scenario you control access to your WCF (SOAP) service using Service Identities managed by Azure AD Access Control.
trans-unit.target: WCF (SOAP) Service with Federated Authentication.In this scenario you control access to your WCF (SOAP) service using Service Identities managed by Azure AD Access Control.

trans-unit.source: WCF (SOAP) Service with Federated Authentication, Identities in Active Directory. In this scenario you control access to your WCF (SOAP) web service using identities managed by corporate Windows Server Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: WCF (SOAP) Service with Federated Authentication, Identities in Active Directory. In this scenario you control access to your WCF (SOAP) web service using identities managed by corporate Windows Server Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: WCF (REST) Service With Federated Authentication.In this scenario you control access to your WCF (REST) service using Service Identities managed by Azure AD Access Control.
trans-unit.target: WCF (REST) Service With Federated Authentication.In this scenario you control access to your WCF (REST) service using Service Identities managed by Azure AD Access Control.

trans-unit.source: WCF (REST) Service With Live ID / Microsoft Account, Facebook, Google, Yahoo!, Open ID. In this scenario you control access to your WCF (REST) service using Internet identity such as Live ID / Microsoft Account.
trans-unit.target: WCF (REST) Service With Live ID / Microsoft Account, Facebook, Google, Yahoo!, Open ID. In this scenario you control access to your WCF (REST) service using Internet identity such as Live ID / Microsoft Account.

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET Web App to REST WCF Service Using Shared SWT Token. In this scenario you have distributed application with front end ASP.NET web app and downstream REST service and you want to flow end user's context through physical tiers.
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET Web App to REST WCF Service Using Shared SWT Token. In this scenario you have distributed application with front end ASP.NET web app and downstream REST service and you want to flow end user's context through physical tiers.

trans-unit.source: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) Authorization In Claims-Aware Applications and Services. In this scenario you want to implement authorization logic in your app based on roles.
trans-unit.target: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) Authorization In Claims-Aware Applications and Services. In this scenario you want to implement authorization logic in your app based on roles.

trans-unit.source: Claims-Based Authorization In Claims-Aware Applications and Services. In this scenario you want to implement authorization logic in your app based on complex authorization rules.
trans-unit.target: Claims-Based Authorization In Claims-Aware Applications and Services. In this scenario you want to implement authorization logic in your app based on complex authorization rules.

trans-unit.source: Azure Storage Service Identity and Access Scenarios.In this scenario you need to securely share access to Azure storage blobs and containers.
trans-unit.target: Azure Storage Service Identity and Access Scenarios.In this scenario you need to securely share access to Azure storage blobs and containers.

trans-unit.source: Azure SQL Database Identity and Access Scenarios.SQL Database supports only SQL Server Authentication.
trans-unit.target: Azure SQL Database Identity and Access Scenarios.SQL Database supports only SQL Server Authentication.

trans-unit.source: Windows Authentication (integrated security) is not supported.
trans-unit.target: Windows Authentication (integrated security) is not supported.

trans-unit.source: Users must provide credentials (login and password) every time they connect to SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: Users must provide credentials (login and password) every time they connect to SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Azure Service Bus Identity and Access Scenarios.In this scenario you need securely access Azure Service Bus queues.
trans-unit.target: Azure Service Bus Identity and Access Scenarios.In this scenario you need securely access Azure Service Bus queues.

trans-unit.source: In-Memory Cache Identity and Access Scenarios.In this scenario you need to securely access data managed by in-memory cache.
trans-unit.target: In-Memory Cache Identity and Access Scenarios.In this scenario you need to securely access data managed by in-memory cache.

trans-unit.source: Azure Marketplace Identity and Access Scenarios.In this scenario you need to securely access Azure Marketplace datasets.
trans-unit.target: Azure Marketplace Identity and Access Scenarios.In this scenario you need to securely access Azure Marketplace datasets.

trans-unit.source: This section outlines common identity and access scenarios for different application architectures.
trans-unit.target: This section outlines common identity and access scenarios for different application architectures.

trans-unit.source: In this application architecture scenario your web application may be deployed to Azure or on-premises.
trans-unit.target: In this application architecture scenario your web application may be deployed to Azure or on-premises.

trans-unit.source: The application requires that its users will be authenticated by either corporate Active Directory or Internet identity providers.
trans-unit.target: The application requires that its users will be authenticated by either corporate Active Directory or Internet identity providers.

trans-unit.source: To solve this scenarios use Azure AD Access control and Windows Identity Foundation.
trans-unit.target: To solve this scenarios use Azure AD Access control and Windows Identity Foundation.

trans-unit.source: In this application architecture scenario your WCF (SOAP) service may be deployed to Azure or on-premises.
trans-unit.target: In this application architecture scenario your WCF (SOAP) service may be deployed to Azure or on-premises.

trans-unit.source: The service is being accessed as a downstream service by a web application or even by another web service.
trans-unit.target: The service is being accessed as a downstream service by a web application or even by another web service.

trans-unit.source: You need to control access to it using application specific identity.
trans-unit.target: You need to control access to it using application specific identity.

trans-unit.source: Think of it in terms of the type of app pool account that you used in IIS - although the technology is different, the approaches are similar in that the service is accessed using an application scope account vs. end user account.
trans-unit.target: Think of it in terms of the type of app pool account that you used in IIS - although the technology is different, the approaches are similar in that the service is accessed using an application scope account vs. end user account.

trans-unit.source: Use the Service Identity feature in Azure AD Access control.
trans-unit.target: Use the Service Identity feature in Azure AD Access control.

trans-unit.source: This is similar to the IIS app pool account you were using when deploying your apps to Windows Server and IIS.
trans-unit.target: This is similar to the IIS app pool account you were using when deploying your apps to Windows Server and IIS.

trans-unit.source: Configure Azure AD Access Control to issue SAML tokens that will be handled by WIF at the WCF (SOAP) service.
trans-unit.target: Configure Azure AD Access Control to issue SAML tokens that will be handled by WIF at the WCF (SOAP) service.

trans-unit.source: In this application architecture scenario your WCF (SOAP) service may be deployed to Azure or on-premises.
trans-unit.target: In this application architecture scenario your WCF (SOAP) service may be deployed to Azure or on-premises.

trans-unit.source: You need to control access to it by using an identity that is managed by a corporate Windows Server Active Directory (AD).
trans-unit.target: You need to control access to it by using an identity that is managed by a corporate Windows Server Active Directory (AD).

trans-unit.source: Use Azure AD Access Control configured for federation with Windows Server AD FS.
trans-unit.target: Use Azure AD Access Control configured for federation with Windows Server AD FS.

trans-unit.source: In this case you do not need to configure Service Identity with Azure AD Access Control.
trans-unit.target: In this case you do not need to configure Service Identity with Azure AD Access Control.

trans-unit.source: The agent that needs to access the WCF (SOAP) service provides credentials to AD FS and upon successful authentication is issued the token by AD FS.
trans-unit.target: The agent that needs to access the WCF (SOAP) service provides credentials to AD FS and upon successful authentication is issued the token by AD FS.

trans-unit.source: The token is then submitted to Azure AD Access Control and reissued back to the agent.
trans-unit.target: The token is then submitted to Azure AD Access Control and reissued back to the agent.

trans-unit.source: You need to control access to it using a public Internet identity, such as Live ID / Microsoft Account or Facebook.
trans-unit.target: You need to control access to it using a public Internet identity, such as Live ID / Microsoft Account or Facebook.

trans-unit.source: Use Azure AD Access Control to issue SWT tokens.
trans-unit.target: Use Azure AD Access Control to issue SWT tokens.

trans-unit.source: To handle the SWT token on the REST service side, you can implement a custom token handler and plug it into a WIF pipeline, or you can parse it "manually" without using the WIF infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: To handle the SWT token on the REST service side, you can implement a custom token handler and plug it into a WIF pipeline, or you can parse it "manually" without using the WIF infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: It is important to note that in order to implement this scenario, the application needs to use web browser control to collect end user credentials.
trans-unit.target: It is important to note that in order to implement this scenario, the application needs to use web browser control to collect end user credentials.

trans-unit.source: This makes it unsuitable for scenarios in which the REST service is accessed from an ASP.NET web app.
trans-unit.target: This makes it unsuitable for scenarios in which the REST service is accessed from an ASP.NET web app.

trans-unit.source: It is only suitable for scenarios in which the REST service is being accessed by the user's client application, such as a Windows Phone 7 app or a rich desktop client.
trans-unit.target: It is only suitable for scenarios in which the REST service is being accessed by the user's client application, such as a Windows Phone 7 app or a rich desktop client.

trans-unit.source: The key reason for popping the web browser control is that Internet identities don't natively support active profile scenarios (web services scenario).
trans-unit.target: The key reason for popping the web browser control is that Internet identities don't natively support active profile scenarios (web services scenario).

trans-unit.source: Internet identities mainly support passive profile scenarios (web apps) that rely on browser redirects: this is where web browser control comes handy.
trans-unit.target: Internet identities mainly support passive profile scenarios (web apps) that rely on browser redirects: this is where web browser control comes handy.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario you have a distributed application with a front-end ASP.NET web app and a downstream REST service and you want to maintain the end user's context across physical tiers.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario you have a distributed application with a front-end ASP.NET web app and a downstream REST service and you want to maintain the end user's context across physical tiers.

trans-unit.source: This is sometimes needed when implementing authorization logic or logging based on the end user's identity in the downstream REST service.
trans-unit.target: This is sometimes needed when implementing authorization logic or logging based on the end user's identity in the downstream REST service.

trans-unit.source: Configure Azure AD Access Control to issue SWT token.
trans-unit.target: Configure Azure AD Access Control to issue SWT token.

trans-unit.source: The SWT token is issued to the front-end ASP.NET web app and then shared with the downstream REST service.
trans-unit.target: The SWT token is issued to the front-end ASP.NET web app and then shared with the downstream REST service.

trans-unit.source: In this case, there is only one relying party configured in Azure AD Access Control.
trans-unit.target: In this case, there is only one relying party configured in Azure AD Access Control.

trans-unit.source: However, there are several caveats:
trans-unit.target: However, there are several caveats:

trans-unit.source: Since WIF does not provide a SWT token handler out of the box you need to implement a custom token handler to be used with the ASP.NET web app.
trans-unit.target: Since WIF does not provide a SWT token handler out of the box you need to implement a custom token handler to be used with the ASP.NET web app.

trans-unit.source: You should rely on the heavy lifting that WIF does to support the WS-Federation protocol that relies on browser redirects vs. implementing it yourself.
trans-unit.target: You should rely on the heavy lifting that WIF does to support the WS-Federation protocol that relies on browser redirects vs. implementing it yourself.

trans-unit.source: When implementing a SWT custom token handler, make sure the bootstrap token is being addressed to make sure it's retained.
trans-unit.target: When implementing a SWT custom token handler, make sure the bootstrap token is being addressed to make sure it's retained.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise you won't be able to share it and send it to the downstream REST service.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise you won't be able to share it and send it to the downstream REST service.

trans-unit.source: You don't have to use WIF on a REST service; rather, you can parse the token "manually" since there is no need to handle redirects in this case.
trans-unit.target: You don't have to use WIF on a REST service; rather, you can parse the token "manually" since there is no need to handle redirects in this case.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario you need to implement authorization in your web application or service based on user roles: user with required roles get access and those that don't have required roles are denied.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario you need to implement authorization in your web application or service based on user roles: user with required roles get access and those that don't have required roles are denied.

trans-unit.source: Simply put, your application needs to answer simple question - is the user in role X?
trans-unit.target: Simply put, your application needs to answer simple question - is the user in role X?

trans-unit.source: There are several ways to solve this scenario.
trans-unit.target: There are several ways to solve this scenario.

trans-unit.source: You can use Azure AD Access Control, WIF Claims Authentication Manager, samlSecurityTokenRequirement mapping, or Customer Role Manager.
trans-unit.target: You can use Azure AD Access Control, WIF Claims Authentication Manager, samlSecurityTokenRequirement mapping, or Customer Role Manager.

trans-unit.source: WIF is used in all cases.
trans-unit.target: WIF is used in all cases.

trans-unit.source: WIF supports the IPrincipal.IsInRole("MyRole") method.
trans-unit.target: WIF supports the IPrincipal.IsInRole("MyRole") method.

trans-unit.source: In most of the cases the key is to make sure there is role type claim with URI of http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/role in the token so that WIF can successfully verify role membership when the IsInRole method is called.
trans-unit.target: In most of the cases the key is to make sure there is role type claim with URI of http://schemas.microsoft.com/ws/2008/06/identity/claims/role in the token so that WIF can successfully verify role membership when the IsInRole method is called.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD Access Control.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Access Control.

trans-unit.source: In this implementation the Azure AD Access Control claims transformation rule engine is used.
trans-unit.target: In this implementation the Azure AD Access Control claims transformation rule engine is used.

trans-unit.source: Using the claims transformation rule engine rules you can transform any incoming claim into a role type claim so that when the token hits the application or a service WIF can parse this role claim to make sure IsInRole method call is succesful.
trans-unit.target: Using the claims transformation rule engine rules you can transform any incoming claim into a role type claim so that when the token hits the application or a service WIF can parse this role claim to make sure IsInRole method call is succesful.

trans-unit.source: WIF ClaimsAuthenticationManager.
trans-unit.target: WIF ClaimsAuthenticationManager.

trans-unit.source: In this implementation use ClaimsAuthenticationManager as WIF's extensibility point.
trans-unit.target: In this implementation use ClaimsAuthenticationManager as WIF's extensibility point.

trans-unit.source: Using this approach you transform any arbitrary incoming claims to a role claim type at the application.
trans-unit.target: Using this approach you transform any arbitrary incoming claims to a role claim type at the application.

trans-unit.source: The complexity of the transformation is only limited by the code you write.
trans-unit.target: The complexity of the transformation is only limited by the code you write.

trans-unit.source: samlSecurityTokenRequriement mapping.
trans-unit.target: samlSecurityTokenRequriement mapping.

trans-unit.source: In this implementation you use the samlSecurityTokenRequirement configuration in web.config to tell WIF which claim types behave as if they were role claim types.
trans-unit.target: In this implementation you use the samlSecurityTokenRequirement configuration in web.config to tell WIF which claim types behave as if they were role claim types.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the token carries a claim of group type, you can map it to role claim type.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the token carries a claim of group type, you can map it to role claim type.

trans-unit.source: You can achieve only simple mappings using this approach.
trans-unit.target: You can achieve only simple mappings using this approach.

trans-unit.source: Custom RoleManager. In this implementation you implement custom RoleManger.
trans-unit.target: Custom RoleManager. In this implementation you implement custom RoleManger.

trans-unit.source: WIF is used to inspect the incoming claims when implementing custom RoleManager interface methods such as GetAllRoles().
trans-unit.target: WIF is used to inspect the incoming claims when implementing custom RoleManager interface methods such as GetAllRoles().

trans-unit.target: Refer to the following resources to implement this scenario:

trans-unit.target: In this scenario you need to implement complex authorization logic in your web application or service and the IsInRole() method is not satisfactory for your authorization needs.

trans-unit.source: If your authorization approach relies on roles then consider implementing role-based access control outlined in previous section.
trans-unit.target: If your authorization approach relies on roles then consider implementing role-based access control outlined in previous section.

trans-unit.target: Use ClaimsAuthorizationManager as the WIF extensibility point.

trans-unit.source: ClaimsAuthorizationManager allows external access check calls so that your application code looks cleaner and more maintainable than when access checks implemented in the application's code.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario you need to securely share access to Azure storage blobs and containers.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario you need to securely share access to Azure storage blobs and containers.

trans-unit.source: Use Shared Access Signatures.
trans-unit.target: Use Shared Access Signatures.

trans-unit.source: To access your storage service account from your own application, use the shared hash that is available through Azure portal when you configure and manage your storage service accounts.
trans-unit.target: To access your storage service account from your own application, use the shared hash that is available through Azure portal when you configure and manage your storage service accounts.

trans-unit.source: When you want to give someone else access to the blobs and containers in your storage service account use Shared Access Signatures URL's.
trans-unit.target: When you want to give someone else access to the blobs and containers in your storage service account use Shared Access Signatures URL's.

trans-unit.source: Pay special attention to securely managing the information to avoid its exposure; also, pay special attention to the lifetime of the Shared Access Signatures.

trans-unit.source: The Service Bus and Azure AD Access Control have a special relationship in that each Service Bus service namespace is paired with a matching Access Control service namespace of the same name, with the suffix "-sb".
trans-unit.target: The Service Bus and Azure AD Access Control have a special relationship in that each Service Bus service namespace is paired with a matching Access Control service namespace of the same name, with the suffix "-sb".

trans-unit.source: The reason for this special relationship is in the way that Service Bus and Access Control manage their mutual trust relationship and the associated cryptographic secrets.
trans-unit.target: The reason for this special relationship is in the way that Service Bus and Access Control manage their mutual trust relationship and the associated cryptographic secrets.

trans-unit.source: Use the shared key that's available through your Marketplace subscription.

trans-unit.source: This section outlines security knobs for Windows Identity Foundation and Azure AD Access Control.
trans-unit.target: This section outlines security knobs for Windows Identity Foundation and Azure AD Access Control.

trans-unit.source: Use it as a basic security checklist for these technologies when designing and deploying your application.
trans-unit.target: Use it as a basic security checklist for these technologies when designing and deploying your application.

trans-unit.source: The following are key security knobs of WIF. The information below is a digest from <linkText>WIF Design Considerations</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Windows Identity Foundation (WIF) Security for ASP.NET Web Applications - Threats & Countermeasures</linkText><title></title> .
trans-unit.target: The following are key security knobs of WIF. The information below is a digest from <linkText>WIF Design Considerations</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Windows Identity Foundation (WIF) Security for ASP.NET Web Applications - Threats & Countermeasures</linkText><title></title> .

trans-unit.source: IssuerNameRegistry.
trans-unit.target: IssuerNameRegistry.

trans-unit.source: Specifies trusted Security Token Services (STS's).
trans-unit.target: Specifies trusted Security Token Services (STS's).

trans-unit.source: Make sure only trusted STS are listed.
trans-unit.target: Make sure only trusted STS are listed.

trans-unit.source: cookieHandler requireSsl="true".
trans-unit.target: cookieHandler requireSsl="true".

trans-unit.source: Specifies whether session cookies transferred over the SSL protocol.
trans-unit.target: Specifies whether session cookies transferred over the SSL protocol.

trans-unit.source: wsFederation's requireHttps="true".
trans-unit.target: wsFederation's requireHttps="true".

trans-unit.source: Specifies whether the federation protocol communication with identity provider performed over SSL protocol.
trans-unit.target: Specifies whether the federation protocol communication with identity provider performed over SSL protocol.

trans-unit.source: tokenReplayDetection enabled="true".
trans-unit.target: tokenReplayDetection enabled="true".

trans-unit.source: Specifies whether token replay detection feature is enabled.
trans-unit.target: Specifies whether token replay detection feature is enabled.

trans-unit.source: Be aware that this feature creates server affinity as it manages local copies of used tokens.
trans-unit.target: Be aware that this feature creates server affinity as it manages local copies of used tokens.

trans-unit.source: audienceUris.
trans-unit.target: audienceUris.

trans-unit.source: Specifies intended audience of the token.
trans-unit.target: Specifies intended audience of the token.

trans-unit.source: If your application receives a token that was not intended for your app it will be rejected by WIF.
trans-unit.target: If your application receives a token that was not intended for your app it will be rejected by WIF.

trans-unit.source: requestValidation and httpRuntime requestValidationType.
trans-unit.target: requestValidation and httpRuntime requestValidationType.

trans-unit.source: Enables/disables ASP.NET validation feature.
trans-unit.target: Enables/disables ASP.NET validation feature.

trans-unit.source: See guidance as outlined in <linkText>Windows Identity Foundation (WIF): A Potentially Dangerous Request.Form Value Was Detected from the Client</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: See guidance as outlined in <linkText>Windows Identity Foundation (WIF): A Potentially Dangerous Request.Form Value Was Detected from the Client</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Consider the following security knobs in Azure AD Access Control deployment.
trans-unit.target: Consider the following security knobs in Azure AD Access Control deployment.

trans-unit.source: The information below is a digest from <linkText>ACS Security Guidelines</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Certificates and Keys Management Guidelines</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The information below is a digest from <linkText>ACS Security Guidelines</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Certificates and Keys Management Guidelines</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: STS tokens expiration.
trans-unit.target: STS tokens expiration.

trans-unit.source: Use Azure AD Access Control management portal to set aggressive token expiration.
trans-unit.target: Use Azure AD Access Control management portal to set aggressive token expiration.

trans-unit.source: Data validation when using the Error URL feature.
trans-unit.target: Data validation when using the Error URL feature.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD Access Control Error URL feature requires anonymous access to the app's page where it sends error messages.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Access Control Error URL feature requires anonymous access to the app's page where it sends error messages.

trans-unit.source: Assume all data coming to this page as dangerous from untrusted source.
trans-unit.target: Assume all data coming to this page as dangerous from untrusted source.

trans-unit.source: Encrypting tokens for highly sensitive scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Encrypting tokens for highly sensitive scenarios.

trans-unit.source: To mitigate threat of information disclosure that available in the token consider encrypting the tokens.
trans-unit.target: To mitigate threat of information disclosure that available in the token consider encrypting the tokens.

trans-unit.source: Encrypting cookies using RSA when deploying to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Encrypting cookies using RSA when deploying to Azure.

trans-unit.source: WIF encrypts cookies using DPAPI by default.
trans-unit.target: WIF encrypts cookies using DPAPI by default.

trans-unit.source: It creates server affinity and may result in exceptions when deployed to web farm and Azure environments.
trans-unit.target: It creates server affinity and may result in exceptions when deployed to web farm and Azure environments.

trans-unit.source: Use RSA instead in web farm and Azure scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Use RSA instead in web farm and Azure scenarios.

trans-unit.source: Token signing certificates.
trans-unit.target: Token signing certificates.

trans-unit.source: Renew token signing certificates periodically to avoid denial of service.
trans-unit.target: Renew token signing certificates periodically to avoid denial of service.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD Access Control signs all security tokens it issues.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Access Control signs all security tokens it issues.

trans-unit.source: X.509 certificates are used for signing when you build an application that consumes SAML tokens issued by ACS.
trans-unit.target: X.509 certificates are used for signing when you build an application that consumes SAML tokens issued by ACS.

trans-unit.source: When signing certificates expire you will receive errors when trying to request a token.
trans-unit.target: When signing certificates expire you will receive errors when trying to request a token.

trans-unit.source: Token signing keys.
trans-unit.target: Token signing keys.

trans-unit.source: Renew token signing keys periodically to avoid denial of service.
trans-unit.target: Renew token signing keys periodically to avoid denial of service.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD Access Control signs all security tokens it issues.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Access Control signs all security tokens it issues.

trans-unit.source: 256-bit symmetric signing keys are used when you build an application that consumes SWT tokens issued by ACS.
trans-unit.target: 256-bit symmetric signing keys are used when you build an application that consumes SWT tokens issued by ACS.

trans-unit.source: When signing keys expire you will receive errors when trying to request a token.
trans-unit.target: When signing keys expire you will receive errors when trying to request a token.

trans-unit.source: Token encryption certificates.
trans-unit.target: Token encryption certificates.

trans-unit.source: Renew token encryption certificates periodically to avoid denial of service.
trans-unit.target: Renew token encryption certificates periodically to avoid denial of service.

trans-unit.source: Token encryption is required if a relying party application is a web service using proof-of-possession tokens over the WS-Trust protocol, in other cases token encryption is optional.
trans-unit.target: Token encryption is required if a relying party application is a web service using proof-of-possession tokens over the WS-Trust protocol, in other cases token encryption is optional.

trans-unit.source: When encryption certificates expire you will receive errors when trying to request a token.
trans-unit.target: When encryption certificates expire you will receive errors when trying to request a token.

trans-unit.source: Token decryption certificates.
trans-unit.target: Token decryption certificates.

trans-unit.source: Renew token decryption certificates periodically to avoid denial of service.
trans-unit.target: Renew token decryption certificates periodically to avoid denial of service.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD Access Control can accept encrypted tokens from WS-Federation identity providers (for example, AD FS 2.0).
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Access Control can accept encrypted tokens from WS-Federation identity providers (for example, AD FS 2.0).

trans-unit.source: An X.509 certificate hosted in Azure AD Access Control is used for decryption.
trans-unit.target: An X.509 certificate hosted in Azure AD Access Control is used for decryption.

trans-unit.source: When decryption certificates expire you will receive errors when trying to request a token.
trans-unit.target: When decryption certificates expire you will receive errors when trying to request a token.

trans-unit.source: Service identity credentials.
trans-unit.target: Service identity credentials.

trans-unit.source: Renew Service Identity credentials periodically to avoid denial of service.
trans-unit.target: Renew Service Identity credentials periodically to avoid denial of service.

trans-unit.source: Service identities use credentials that are configured globally for your Azure AD Access Control namespace that allow applications or clients to authenticate directly with Azure AD Access Control and receive a token.
trans-unit.target: Service identities use credentials that are configured globally for your Azure AD Access Control namespace that allow applications or clients to authenticate directly with Azure AD Access Control and receive a token.

trans-unit.source: There are three credential types that Azure AD Access Control service identity can be associated with: Symmetric key, Password, and X.509 certificate.
trans-unit.target: There are three credential types that Azure AD Access Control service identity can be associated with: Symmetric key, Password, and X.509 certificate.

trans-unit.source: You will start receiving exception when the credentials are expired.
trans-unit.target: You will start receiving exception when the credentials are expired.

trans-unit.source: Azure AD Access Control Management Service account credentials.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD Access Control Management Service account credentials.

trans-unit.source: Renew Management service credentials periodically to avoid denial of service.
trans-unit.target: Renew Management service credentials periodically to avoid denial of service.

trans-unit.source: The Azure AD Access Control Management Service is a key component that allows you to programmatically manage and configure settings for your Azure AD Access Control namespace.
trans-unit.target: The Azure AD Access Control Management Service is a key component that allows you to programmatically manage and configure settings for your Azure AD Access Control namespace.

trans-unit.source: There are three credential types that the Management service account can be associated with.
trans-unit.target: There are three credential types that the Management service account can be associated with.

trans-unit.source: These are symmetric key, password, and an X.509 certificate.
trans-unit.target: These are symmetric key, password, and an X.509 certificate.

trans-unit.source: You will start receiving exception when the credentials are expired.
trans-unit.target: You will start receiving exception when the credentials are expired.

trans-unit.source: WS-Federation identity provider signing and encryption certificates.
trans-unit.target: WS-Federation identity provider signing and encryption certificates.

trans-unit.source: Query for WS-Federation identity provider's certificate validity to avoid denial of service.
trans-unit.target: Query for WS-Federation identity provider's certificate validity to avoid denial of service.

trans-unit.source: WS-Federation identity provider certificate is available through its metadata.
trans-unit.target: WS-Federation identity provider certificate is available through its metadata.

trans-unit.source: When configuring WS-Federation identity provider, such as AD FS, the WS-Federation signing certificate is configured through WS-Federation metadata available via URL or as a file.
trans-unit.target: When configuring WS-Federation identity provider, such as AD FS, the WS-Federation signing certificate is configured through WS-Federation metadata available via URL or as a file.

trans-unit.source: After the WS-Federation identity provider configured use Azure AD Access Control management service to query it for its certificates validness.
trans-unit.target: After the WS-Federation identity provider configured use Azure AD Access Control management service to query it for its certificates validness.

trans-unit.source: When the certificate expires you will start receiving exceptions.
trans-unit.target: When the certificate expires you will start receiving exceptions.

trans-unit.source: All scenarios and solutions outlined in this topic are valid when the application is hosted on Azure Websites.
trans-unit.target: All scenarios and solutions outlined in this topic are valid when the application is hosted on Azure Websites.

trans-unit.source: All scenarios and solutions outlined in this topic are valid when the application is hosted on Azure Virtual Machines.
trans-unit.target: All scenarios and solutions outlined in this topic are valid when the application is hosted on Azure Virtual Machines.
